results.title: Masseur
results.creator_credit: John O'Brien, Donna Cavanough and Helen Linthorne
results.brief_description: The power of touch is highlighted in this short drama about an old man who experiences an outpouring of hidden emotions and grief after receiving a massage.

results.title: Massage for Health
results.creator_credit: Healing Arts Home Video, Steven Adams and Johanna Demetrakas
results.brief_description: You can take the fitness of your mind and body into your own hands with “Massage for Health”. You can combat stress, enhance your physical beauty, or improve your athletic performance. They’ll cover every aspect of massage as they cover virtually every inch of your body. You’ll learn the safe, and correct way to prepare for, and give, and receive massage. With a little practice this video will give you all you need to experience new levels of strength, relaxation and well being.

results.title: Massacre in Nanjing = Tu Cheng Xue Ji
results.creator_credit: Nanjing Film Production Company and Luo Guanqun
results.brief_description:
This film is reputed to be the first to ever dramatic retelling of the events leading from the Japanese invasion of Nanjing, on Dec. 13, 1937. Over the course of six weeks, 300 000 people were brutally massacred. The contents of the film range from heart-rending to absurd, as the director tries to approach this highly sensitive event in modern Chinese history.

Crowds of civilians flee across a bridge, crowding onto boats in an effort to escape the onslaught of the Japanese military. Amongst them are the government officials, abandoning their posts out of sheer terror. A foreign blonde woman drives through the carnage in black car. Arriving at a makeshift hospital, she witnesses the hardship and sufferng the Chinese people are undergoing at the hands of the bombarding. She finds a doctor named Zhan and tells him that there is time for them to secure passage on the last of the departing American ships.

The invading force rounds up those left behind in the city and takes photos as they gun them down. However, it is immediately visible that there have been issues in casting actual Japanese, as these supposed “foreign invaders” all speak fluent Chinese. This accentuates a point of ambivalence which escalates in tandem with the scale of violence they perform.

At first, the Japanese commander is disturbed that the Yangtze is running red with blood: This does not conform with the image they purport of being the liberators of China. They allow 200 000 refugees to flee into the 3-square-kilometer rat nest of the “Safety Area”. Fan, a frightened Chinese photographer and householder, is threatened to develop the Japanese photos of the carnage, or they will burn down his house, kill his children and rape his pregnant wife.

Strict censorship is enforced so as to prevent news of the carnage from being leaked to the public.

Meanwhile Japanese women in traditional kimono smile and scatter sweets along the ground for the frightenned locals who stand in fear. This scene is actually quite well done, and sets a precedent for the extremes of absurdity we will encounter later in the film. Meanwhile, men are led into the mountains and summarily executed by beyonetting and machine-gunning.

It is not long after before the Japanese invade the church and murder the people inside. The soldiers want to defend themselves, but doctor Zhan implores them to not act, otherwise the Japanese will slaughter the refugees. They throw all their weapons in the lake, except one man who conceals his pistol in a bookshelf. Under the pretext of searching for Chinese soldiers, the Japanese invade the Safety Area and round up all the refugees.

The film’s most powerful scene takes place in the Safety Area’s library, when a stereotypical Japanese man kicks a newly born child on the ground and beyonets it, lifting it up above him and laughing despicably as he lets the newborn’s blood trickle down all over his face. Then they gang rape the mother and her 12 year old daughter before murdering them both. The total collapse of civilization is symbolised by the bookshelf, full of works on ethics, history and human achievements, collapsing on the ground.

The only thing left for them to do is to record the atrocities. Fan, whose family was murdered, has the photos and risks his life to retrieve them from his house. He gives his life to save Zhan and the photos. One Chinese man tries to surrender the photos to get the photos back, but is tricked into giving the wrong photos.

The variety of atrocities depicted include decapitation, mass graves where people are buried alive, murdering of wounded, and putting an old man in a bag and setting it on fire.

The film ends with a scene of Zhan trapped in the belltower of a burning church. With no way to get out or survive he rings the bells to symbolise his never-ending struggle to tell the world of what has happened.
(3 stars - James Donald; June 8, 2011)

results.title: Mass transit: up, up and away
results.brief_description: Argues that the car is a real hazard in urban societies, as well as being a cause of pollution. Examines various alternative means of mass transportation.

results.title: Mass spectrometry
results.creator_credit: John Wiley and Sons, Communications Group West, Robert L Pescok, James L. Sudmeier and Mallory Pearce
results.brief_description: Presents the technique of mass spectrometry, shows how the instrument operates, how a mass spectrum is obtained, the relationship between precise molecular weight and the chemical formula, and some of the common ways in which molecules fragment. Intended for classes in analytical and organic chemistry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Wiley and Sons, Communications Group West, Robert L Pescok, James L. Sudmeier and Mallory Pearce

results.title: Mass radiography
results.creator_credit: Seven League Unit, H.M. Nieter and S.O. Siecki
results.brief_description: By means of mobile X-Ray units it is possible to take radiograms of large numbers of people I a relatively short time. These photographs are then examined by expert radiologists, and diagnoses made. In this film, the visit of a mobile X-Ray unit to a British factory is shown. (The film is intended for use by Medical Officers and Health and Welfare Officers when they are planning to send a mobile X-Ray unit to a place not previously visited). Also made for the prevention of tuberculosis. Narrated by Lionel Gamlin.

results.title: Mass of the electron
results.creator_credit: Educational Services, Stephen White and Kevin Smith
results.brief_description: Using a cathode ray tube encircled by a current carrying a loop of wire, measurements are taken which enable the demonstrator to calculate the mass of the electron with reference to the Millikan Experiment. The calculations are brought out in detail step by step. Part of a course in physics for Secondary Schools by Prof. Eric M. Rogers, Princeton University.

results.title: Mass media and adult education
results.creator_credit: Kratky Film, Unesco and Rudolf Krejcik
results.brief_description: Radio, television, film, the press and books have become a part of our immediate environment. Cassettes, teledistribution, satellites and other new techniques of information storage, processing and broadcasting will be equally familiar to us before long. The film shows experiments being made to help the promotion and development of adult education in Canada, Colombia, India, Japan, Tunisia, USA, USSR, & Zambia.

results.title: Mass communications and society: a mirror held up to reality
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University and John Miller
results.brief_description: First in a series of four films shot in Kansas City in August 1976, showing the ABC’s television coverage of the Republican Convention. The key areas are shown and the main figures explain their role and attitude towards the politicians and towards their competitors in the other networks. Also shown are the final editorial briefing and the production meeting, as well as the arrivals and speeches of Ronald Reagan and President ford.

results.title: Mass and weight
results.brief_description: Shows the behaviour of a bowling ball in an actual bowling alley, and in imaginary alleys at the North Pole, at the Equator, on the moon and in intergalactic space to explore the concepts of mass and weight. Explains the relationship between gravitational and inertial mass.
